Some feared it meant destruction, an abattoir-era where the human race and many others were prey and nourishment. Other, were uncertain, believing the Lord of R’lyeh would teach men to laugh and revel and kill.

Those in the second camp were the most correct. Cthulhu did rise up again free from his slumber, free to make good on his antique dreams. But his ambitions were not a destroyer nor even, rightly, a conqueror. No, Cthulhu rose as an evangelist, high priest of unknowable, fabulously dangerous gods. And the shock of his presence, the power of his ministry, is today known as the Dream.

As the Old One arose, humanity was psychically damaged beyond repair. Previously, only the most ‘sensitive’ of souls could perceive the movement and desires of Cthulhu. Unfettered, free to preach, the world itself went insane. No one knows how long it took but soon, terribly soon, after Cthulhu’s release, humanity had fallen. Infected by the alien morality of the High Priest, humans became shrieking things, immoral and barbaric, completely without scruple or the faintest notion of consequence. Society and culture fell apart until humanity simply screamed the name of its new King and converted to a blind and idiot religion they could barely comprehend.

Except for a small plateau in China, where precautions had been taken.

76598.name: Tezelle
76598.description:
A tile laying, domino-style game played within the confines of a board using 2x1 oblong shaped thick cardboard tiles of a diamond design utilising seven colours.
The game box contains
4 page rules sheet in 6 languages.
a 48cm square board with 14 x 14 squares thereon onto which the tiles cover 2 adjacent squares.
a pad of score sheets.
4 x cardboard racks for players to display their tiles to them whilst concealing from other players.
a box containing 49 different tiles.

To start the game all the tiles are placed face down on the table and each player selects 8 - 10 tiles [depending upon number of players] and puts them on his/her rack.

The double tiles [coloured triangle the same each end] are numbered 1 - 7 and the player with the lowest numbered double starts the game by placing the tile to cover 2 of the 4 centre squares.

The next player [if wished] matches the end or side of one of his/her tiles and places the tile so that the triangles on the 2 tiles make a coloured square. If the player cannot or chooses not to play a tile the player misses a turn and picks up, if available, a tile from those faced down at the beginning of the game.

Players cannot form squares using triangles of different colours.

The game continues until one player succeeds in playing his last tile [or no player can play]

Matches consist of several games to decide overall winner.

76599.name: Serpent's Skull Player's Guide
76599.description:
Publisher blurb:

This guide seeks to aid players preparing to take part in the Serpent’s Skull Adventure Path, to arm them with spoiler-free details and rules elements useful in the forthcoming challenges, and to help create backgrounds that easily mesh with the campaign.

Along with advice for players of every race and character class in the Pathfinder Roleplaying Game—including those in the newly released Advanced Player’s Guide—details on Sargava, the country in closest proximity to the campaign’s events, and of the Jenivere, the ship conveying the PCs to adventure, should help ground players in the circumstances and events of this new Adventure Path.

Those looking for even more details and options for exotic adventures should take a look at Pathfinder Player’s Companion: Sargava.

76600.name: Bl'nd P'g without any Eyes
76600.description:
From Play The Game description:

Game for two players

Circa 1920

Information on gameplay from Play the Game by Brian Love.

Two farmers try to force their apparently 1-eyed if not totally blind pigs up the road to market. The route is a minefield of detours. The only consolation is that the players get to control 2 pigs rather than 1 and can decide in which order the beasts shall be moved nearer to the finish enclosure. You roll two dice and then determine which one will move . Both of your pigs must get to the finish line in order to win. If your pig gets to a field marked IN it must enter the field and go through it until it gets back to the out gate. Once 1 pig has reached the MARKET you can only roll one die for the remaining pig.

76601.name: Elevator Action
76601.description:
From Wikipedia

Elevator Action (エレベーターアクション, Erebētā Akushon?) is a 1983 arcade game by Taito. It debuted during the "Golden Age of Arcade Games". Innovative in gameplay, this game was fairly popular for many years. The musician was Yoshino Imamura. The game was followed by a sequel, Elevator Action II (also known as Elevator Action Returns).

76602.name: Mutant
76602.description:
User Summary:

The core set for Mutant 2089. Also known as "Nya Mutant" or "New Mutant". Inspired by the Cyberpunk wave in the time, the setting changed from being in an agricultural post-apocalyptic society to being in huge megacities controlled by super-corporations.

Back of the box:

This is the main box containing the core rulebook for the Swedish classic "Mutant", a role playing game set in a post-apocalyptic future, where technology has been reverted into pre-industrial revolution level. It's base on the Basic Role Playing System.

Setting: Most people live as peasants, but there are "forbidden zones" where the radiation level is still high and where lost technology can be found. Players play physically or mentally mutated human beings, or mutated animals (humanoids).

76603.name: Patrician III
76603.description:
From Wikipedia

Patrician III: Rise of the Hanse is the latest computer game from Ascaron in their Patrician series. It is a game simulating trading, piracy, politics, and economy. The series was originally released in German, as Patrizier and Patrizier 2. Patrizier 2 had an add on release called Patrizier 2: Aufschwung der Hanse. Patrician 3 is the international release in English of the combined Patrizier 2 and its expansion. The German version was released in 2000 and the English version in 2003. The Patrician series will be continued in Autumn 2010 with The Patrician IV, since Kalypso Media bought the licenses from the insolvent Ascaron company.

76604.name: Mystery House
76604.description:
[From Wikipedia: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mystery_House]

Mystery House is an adventure computer game released in 1980 by Roberta and Ken Williams for the Apple II. The game is remembered as one of the first adventure games to feature computer graphics and the first game produced by On-Line Systems, the company which would evolve into Sierra On-Line. Because of its use of graphics, GamePro named Mystery House the 51st most important game of all time in 2007.

76605.name: BiPlane
76605.description:
User Summary

An early arcade shooter that allowed to 2 players to face each other in bi-plane combat.

76606.name: Fury of the Furries
76606.description:
Fury of the Furries is a platform/puzzler game released by Kalisto Entertainment for the Amiga, Amiga CD32, Macintosh and MS-DOS systems. (...)

The player guides a small furry, bouncy and fragile Tiny across eight regions of the land, Desert, Lagoon, Forest, Pyramids, Mountains, Factory, Village, and latterly the Castle where one must defeat the Wicked One. The regions each have unique music, color schemes and styles. Each has 10 separate levels and a collection of secret bonus levels. The final stage of the game has the player entering the machine (which turns out to be a large industrial complex) and destroying it. Along the way the player must avoid various perils, such as monsters, spikes and acid.

The game's primary unique feature is Tiny's ability to transform itself into four different forms: yellow, green, red and blue. Different skills are required at different points, and not all forms are available in all levels. Particularly in levels which are primarily puzzlers, the player may encounter fields which activate and deactivate certain powers.

In its yellow form, it controls the element of fire, allowing it to shoot fireballs. In its red form, it controls the element of earth, allowing it to eat through some elements of the scenery. In its green form, it controls the element of air, allowing it to produce ropes from its hands to swing around the environment and it can also pull different objects with its rope. In its blue form, it controls the element of water, allowing the ability to dive underwater and shooting bubbles that damage hostiles.

Source: Wikipedia, "Furry of the Furries," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

76607.name: Tank! (1974)
76607.description:
[From Wikipedia: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tank_%28arcade_game%29]

Tank is a 2 player arcade game by Atari Inc. subsidiary Kee Games, originally released on November 5, 1974 and designed by Steve Bristow and Lyle Rains. The game is famous for causing such demand that Atari made its "secret" ownership of Kee Games public, merging the company back in to Atari and releasing Tank under the Atari label as well.

76608.name: Death Race
76608.description:
[From Wikipedia: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Death_Race_%28video_game%29]

Death Race is a controversial arcade game, released by Exidy in 1976. While not the first violent video game to appear, it was the first video game to inspire a great deal of protest and controversy in the United States.

76609.name: Defender of the Crown
76609.description:
Cinemaware's Thematic Overview

"In a time of lusty wenches and black-hearted villains, King Richard has been murdered and England thrown into civil war! Amidst the ringing clash of steel and the thunder of charging steeds the bold Saxon knights have chosen you to lead them into battle against the hated Normans. Players will compete in grand tournaments of joust, siege castles and raid enemy strongholds in their attempt to find the lost crown of England. Enlisting the support of Robin Hood, players will have to outwit their enemies to control England and restore order to a war-torn land."

Game Description

Defender of the Crown is set in the Middle Ages, where following the death of King Richard, players assume the role of a Saxon lord, try to fight off Norman hordes and ultimately wrestle for complete control of England. The players will collect valuable resources to build strongholds, amass armies and fight for control of opponents' castles and territories.

Players may engage enemy lords with their armies on the battlefield or contest lands and fame in medieval tournaments. They may also loot the treasuries of opposing lords or lay siege to their castles. Players must also contend with random events such as plague, drought, locusts while fighting for their right to be crowned King of England.

Once a player has taken control of all enemy counties they will be crowned king and win the game.

76610.name: Sea Wolf
76610.description:
From Wikipedia

Sea Wolf is an arcade game by Midway, originally released in 1976. A video game update of an earlier coin-operated electro-mechanical (em) Midway game, Sea Devil, it simulated a naval battle in a virtual submarine environment. The cabinet includes a periscope the player looks through to see the monitor, which also includes a fire button used to fire torpedoes at various targets on the screen.

76611.name: Soletrando Cards
76611.description:
From the back of the box:

There are 594 words to be spelled. The more words you get right, the bigger your chances to win. A game based in the TV Show Soletrando from Caldeirão do Hulk. A pratical and sturdy box for you to take and play any place you want.

Verso da caixa:

São 594 palavras par serem soletradas. Quanto mais palavras você acertar, maiores são as suas chances de vencer. Um jogo baseado no quadro Soletrando do programa Caldeirão do Hulk. Uma caixa prática e resistente para você levar e jogar aonde quiser.

76612.name: Pushover
76612.description:
Pushover is a platform puzzle game developed by Red Rat Software in 1992 for the Amiga, Atari ST, DOS and Super NES. Ocean Software published the game. The game was sponsored by Smiths' British snack Quavers, where the game plot revolved around the Quavers mascot 'Colin Curly' losing his Quavers packets down a giant ant hill (Walkers has since bought the Quavers brand and Colin Curly is no longer used as a mascot). It is then up to the Pushover character 'G.I. Ant', a large soldier ant, to go inside the ant hill and recover the Quavers.

In the SNES version of the game, the aim was to recover bundles of cash dropped down the ant hill by Captain Rat.

The playing field consists of a number of platforms, interconnected by ladders. Most of the platforms hold dominoes. G.I. Ant can rearrange and move them, by carrying one domino at a time. He is allowed to push one domino, and this single push should result in all of the dominoes falling, which opens the exit to the next level.

Source: Wikipedia, "Pushover (video game)," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

76613.name: Lunar Lander

videogameversion.139220: Android (Atari Greatest Hits Arcade Emulation) edition

76613.description:
From Wikipedia

Lunar Lander is an arcade game released by Atari, Inc. in 1979, which uses a vector monitor to display vector graphics. Although not particularly successful, is vector-graphics generator was the impetus of Atari's most successful coin-operated game: Asteroids. The object of the game is to pilot a lunar landing module to a safe touchdown on the moon. Approximately 4,830 units were produced.

76614.name: One Step Beyond
76614.description:
User summary

One Step Beyond is a platform puzzle game developed by Red Rat Software in 1993 as a sequel to Pushover. As with the previous title, the game was sponsored by Smiths' British snack Quavers. The game stars 'Colin Curly', who while playing Pushover is accidentally sucked into a computer and becomes a hero of his own game.

The playing field consist of a number of platform, all of which must be visited before leaving a level. Since most of the platforms hide after the first visit, and some of them have other special functions the aim of the game is to work out the correct route through the levels.

76616.name: Eagle
76616.description:
User Summary

A arcade space/science fiction shoot 'em up from Centuri.

76617.name: Missile Command

videogameversion.139224: Android (Atari Greatest Hits Arcade Emulation) edition

76617.description:
From Wikipedia

Missile Command is a 1980 arcade game by Atari, Inc. that was also licensed to Sega for European release. It is considered one of the most notable games from the Golden Age of Video Arcade Games. The plot of Missile Command is simple: the player's six cities are being attacked by an endless hail of ballistic missiles, some of them even splitting like multiple independently targetable reentry vehicles (MIRVs), and in later levels smart bombs which can evade a less than perfectly targeted missile. As a regional commander of three anti-missile batteries, the player must defend six cities in their zone from being destroyed.

76618.name: Phoenix
76618.description:
From Wikipedia

Phoenix is a popular shoot 'em up arcade game created and manufactured by Amstar Electronics (which was located in Phoenix, Arizona) in 1980, and licensed to Centuri for US distribution, and to Taito for Japanese distribution.

Like many arcade games of that era, Phoenix is a top-down outer space-themed fixed shooter. The player controls a spaceship that moves horizontally at the bottom of the screen, firing upward. Enemies, typically one of two types of birds, appear on the screen above the player's ship, shooting at it and periodically diving towards it in an attempt to crash into it. In addition to the missiles, the ship is equipped with a shield that can be used to zap any of the alien creatures that attempt to crash into the spaceship. However, the player cannot move while the shield is active, and must wait for a short period (approximately five seconds) before using it again.

Phoenix was one of the first full color arcade games, along with Galaxian, so at the time it stood out. Also, it has distinctive shooting sounds that have become very familiar to fans of the genre. Most importantly, the Phoenix mothership was the first video arcade game boss where the boss was presented as a separate challenge.

76619.name: Nutshell
76619.description:
User Summary:

Nutshell is a free story-oriented ruleset that fits comfortably on a 2" x 3.5" business card.

To attempt a challenging feat, a player must risk a coin. The "planner" (game master) offers a choice of a few concealed coins, including the player's. If the player chooses their own coin, the attempt succeeds and yields an extra coin or two for the player.

76620.name: Grand Theft Auto: Liberty City Stories

videogamehonor.30980: 2005 Spike Best Handheld/Mobile Game of the Year Nominee

76620.description:
From Wikipedia

Grand Theft Auto: Liberty City Stories is a sandbox-style action-adventure video game developed by Rockstar North and Rockstar Leeds. It is the ninth game in the Grand Theft Auto series. It was released for the PlayStation Portable in North America on October 25, 2005 and in the United Kingdom (UK) on November 4, 2005. The game was succeeded by Grand Theft Auto: Vice City Stories. It was published and distributed by: Capcom for the Japanese release.

76621.description:
For Tyler Scindere, a lowlife thug-for-pay, his most recent unsavory job may be his last. The victim of a double-cross, Tyler has become a living science experiment, caught in a perpetual hell of pain, hallucinations, and despair. But just as time loses its meaning and Tyler begins to lose his mind, a sliver of hope appears... from an unlikely ally.

Screams from Within is a fixed 60 card Asylum Pack that contains 20 different never-before-seen cards based on the dark mythos of master horror writer H.P. Lovecraft, designed to augment existing decks and add variety to the Call of Cthulhu metagame.

Also included in this cycle is part five of a gripping new short story by Nate French. In the last installment, Erin Morai was trapped in a supernatural menagerie of horrifying beasts, surviving on revolting scraps and subject to mind-bending psychological experiments. Now, we return to the plight of her kidnapper, Tyler Scindere. With his eyes ripped from their sockets, Scindere is horrified by the fact that he is still able to see.

Surrender your mind to the will of your captors...

This is not a stand-alone deck; you must have additional Call of Cthulhu LCG cards to play.
76621.name: Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game – Screams from Within Asylum Pack

40270.name: Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game

boardgamefamily.10579: Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game (LCG)

76623.name: 5 Days a Stranger
76623.description:
From Wikipedia

5 Days a Stranger chronicles the story of a gentleman thief known as Trilby and four others fighting an unknown terror in DeFoe Manor. The story progresses over 5 days, with more story being revealed each day. Dream sequences typically space out the transitions between the events of different days, it has an intuitive version of the AGS interface that ties in with the unique feel of the game. The game has been translated into German, Finnish, Hungarian, Turkish, Italian, and Russian.

The game was created in 2003 with the Adventure Game Studio (AGS) engine and won awards for best game created with the AGS engine in 2003, best gameplay, best dialog scripting, best puzzles, and best scripting. The game has also had many good reviews on adventure game sites

76624.name: We Sing (2009)
76624.description:
"We Sing is a 2009 music video game for the Wii. Developed by Le Cortex, produced by Wired Productions and published by Nordic Games, it is the first singing game to support 4 players simultaneously each with their own microphone.

We Sing is distributed as a software only version, a two microphone and game bonus pack.

It was revealed in May 2010 that sequel titled We Sing Encore was set for a release in July 2010

The gameplay is similar to the SingStar set of video games. Players are required to sing along with music in order to score points, matching pitch and rhythm. The game has anticheat technology whereby tapping or humming will register on the screen but no points will be awarded.

30 Songs

Solo Mode

Multiplayer modes - Group Battle, We Sing, Versus, Pass the Mic, First to 5000. The ability to sing with up to 4 players as a group is a confirmed feature.

Karaoke mode

Customisable backgrounds

Four Microphones

Integrates with a USB hub"

Source: Wikipedia, "We Sing," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

76625.name: Empire Earth

videogameexpansion.81399: Empire Earth: The Art of Conquest

76625.description:
Empire Earth, also known as EE, is a real-time strategy computer game developed by Stainless Steel Studios and released on November 23, 2001. It is the first game in the Empire Earth series. It has been described as very similar to the Age of Empires series, and received positive reviews.

The game requires players to collect resources to construct buildings, produce citizens, and conquer opposing civilizations. Empire Earth spans 500,000 years of world history, which is divided into 14 epochs, beginning with the prehistoric age, and ending with the nano age.

Source: Wikipedia, "Empire Earth," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

76626.name: Rally-X
76626.description:
Rally-X is a maze arcade game that was released by Namco in 1980. It runs on Namco Pac-Man hardware, and was the first Namco game to feature "Special Flags", which would become a recurring object in later games (along with the Galaxian flagship). It was the first game to ever feature a "bonus round." The object is to "capture" all of the flags scattered in the field before the other racers hit you.

Source: Wikipedia, "Rally-X," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

videogame.80840: Arcade's Greatest Hits: The Atari Collection 1

76627.name: Tempest

videogameversion.139239: Android (Atari Greatest Hits Arcade Emulation) edition

videogamecompilation.80840: Arcade's Greatest Hits: The Atari Collection 1

76627.description:
Tempest is an arcade game by Atari Inc., originally designed and programmed by David Theurer. Released in October, 1981, it was fairly popular and had several ports and sequels. The game is also notable for being the first video game with a selectable level of difficulty (determined by the initial starting level). The game is a tube shooter, a type of shoot 'em up where the environment is fixed and viewed from a three-dimensional perspective.

Source: Wikipedia, "Tempest (arcade game)," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

76628.name: Emergency!
76628.description:
“Paging Doctor Ward to the Emergency Clinic – Doctor Ward - Code Blue – STAT!”

It has been a tough shift so far, and the pressure is getting to you; so many patients, not enough time.

Doctor Sanjit needs a hand with pathology, Doctor Gruber is concerned about the patient in the waiting room whose condition may deteriorate rapidly if left untreated.

The patient in front of you needs urgent surgery, but the operating theatre is occupied and there is breakdown in radiology that requires attention.

Curse those budget cuts, we're left with no choice but to park patients in corridors and risk infections.

Both Ambulance docks are full and oh no! another critically injured patient arriving at the helipad, and to make matters worse you haven't even had your morning coffee yet.

-

You and your companions are highly respected doctors working in the high-pressure, environment of the Emergency Clinic, dealing with life and death decisions every day.

Working as a team, you each have to co-operate, using your medical expertise to diagnose and treat patients and manage scarce resources, all the while avoiding worsening conditions, infection outbreaks and crises that threaten the lives of your patients.

-
Emergency! is a co-operative crisis management and resource management game that also includes competitive elements.
Each player assumes the role of a doctor whose job is to work as part of a team to successfully treat sick patients who arrive at the Emergency Clinic and send them home.

Together you must make best use of your own specialist skills, to make life and death decisions affecting; treatment, transport and management of patients using the limited resources available to you, in a high-pressure environment.

As a team you must also deal with numerous infection outbreaks, equipment failures, and deteriorating patient conditions, many of which may lead to drastic situations.

Your Doctor already has a range of specialist skills upon which you may develop, researching new techniques or calling-in other specialists to assist.

To aid you throughout the game, specialised Treatment Rooms also offer additional equipment and bonuses toward treating your Patients. Making best use of these rooms is vital to your success as a team.

76629.name: Gorf
76629.description:
Gorf is an arcade game released in 1981 by Midway Mfg., whose name was advertised as an acronym for "Galactic Orbiting Robot Force". It is a multiple-mission fixed shooter with five distinct modes of play, essentially making it five games in one. It is well-known for its use of synthesized speech, a new feature at the time.

Source: Wikipedia, "Gorf," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

76631.name: Personal Weapons of Charted Space
76631.description:
From the web site:

TA1 is a complete guide to personal armament in the Traveller universe. It condenses and expands data from Book 1, Book 4 and Supplement 4 of the Classic Traveller series, presenting it in one volume for probably the first time. Additional weaponry is also listed, including non-lethal weapons, unusual variants, and special hand-to-hand devices. All weapons are rated for T20 and CT, but can easily be used with most d20 based games!

TA1 also deals with the Imperial weapons permit system, arms suppliers of the Imperium, and expands upon the CT and T20 combat rules. Additional rules permit area attacks, suppression fire and movie-style abuse of handguns while performing daring acrobatic maneuvers!

And as if that wasn't enough, TA1 also has rules for concealing weapons and slipping them past the Starport detectors. Can you really afford to be without your copy?

76633.name: On the Ground
76633.description:
From the web site:

TA3 is a complete guide to privately owned ground vehicles in the Traveller Universe. On the Ground expands on the design sequences found in the Traveller's Handbook, giving tips on vehicle construction and details on such things as "how big is my vehicle" and even rules on towing! There are tips on power plants and what kind of tires to use on some vehicles.

The vehicles in this issue range from steam powered carriages to sleek perfomance motorcycles. These are the vehicles that your players will encounter everyday on most any planet at varied technological levels. Ever wonder how fast that heavy duty truck can go and how much punishment it can take before it falls apart leaving the character stranded? TA #3 tells you those things. Each of the 24 vehicles are fully illustrated and has a full description and vehicle design sequence stats.

Also covered are the corporations that build and service these commercial and private vehicles that are used all across the Imperium! So, go down the the show room and pick out your favorite, select the color and drive off the showroom floor with a new vehicle for all your adventures!

76636.name: Conquest of the Crystal Palace
76636.description:
User Summary
Conquest of the Crystal Palace is a Japanese game for the NES. It is a side-scrolling platformer. The game takes place in a fantasy realm. The main character is a 15 year-old boy named Farron. He travels with his dog, Zap to regain control of the titular Crystal Palace. At the beginning of the story you chose one of three crystals that grant you a special power throughout the game. You can also call on your dog at any time to help you destroy enemies until his life bar depletes.

76637.name: Through the Waves
76637.description:
From the introductioh:

This book is intended for use with Classic Traveller (CT) and T20 – Traveller for the D20 system. Background material is of course also fully compatible with other versions of Traveller.
This volume is the third in a series dealing with vehicles in use in the Traveller universe. It details the range of waterborne vehicles available to travellers at various tech levels.

76638.description:
Tyler Scindere was hired to do a job, plain and simple. But the dangers that face him now are anything but plain, and there’s nothing simple about the dark motives of his employers. Now, the betrayer has become the betrayed, and he’ll need every ounce of courage and wit he can muster if he hopes to remain alive.

The Spoken Covenant is a fixed 60 card Asylum Pack that contains 20 different never-before-seen cards based on the dark mythos of master horror writer H.P. Lovecraft, designed to augment existing decks and add variety to the Call of Cthulhu metagame.

This is not a stand-alone deck; you must have additional Call of Cthulhu LCG cards to play.
76638.name: Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game – The Spoken Covenant Asylum Pack

40270.name: Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game

boardgamefamily.10579: Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game (LCG)

76639.name: Fighting Ships of the Solomani Confederation
76639.description:
From the web site:

The most potent and the most dangerous of the opponents of the Third Imperium are the humans of the Solomani Confederation. This volume of the Traveller's Aide Series introduces you to the naval forces of the Solomani.

TA9 provides you with an indepth look into the structure and organization of the Solomani Navy as it has deployed in the current war with the Imperium, as well as providing you detailed data on over 30 ships in the Confederation fleets including:

* The newly deployed, powerful Bejing Class Fast Dreadnought
* The small yet versatile Viper Class Fighter/Bomber
* The commonly encountered Yamamoto Class Strike Cruiser
* The dreaded Zhukov Class Troop Carrier
* The tried and true Victory Class Battlecruiser
* The technologically advanced Zeus Class Battlecruiser
* The Solomani Secret Police's Purity Class Recon Frigate
* The standard Defender Class Light Patrol Cruiser

Each comes with a description of the function and purpose of the ship, as well as detailed design specifications.

As with the original Fighting Ships, this volume covers most every range of ship class ranging from mammoth dreadnoughts and battleships, to the smallest of fighters, to the non-combat support vessels needed to tend the fleet.

These are the vessels that fought in the Solomani Rim War. Traveller players in other eras may run into earlier or later versions of these ships, making TA9 and indispensable tool for Traveller campaigns of any era!

76640.name: 76 Gunmen
76640.description:
From the web site:

This issue of the Traveller's Aide contains 76 pre-generated characters for both the Traveller20 (T20) and Classic Traveller (CT) game systems! This time saving issue is perfect for the harried referee needing quick opponents for the characters when they unexpectedly decide to explore the darker recesses of the starports fringe or pick a fight in the local bar with the mouthy marines from 154th Lift Infantry Regiment. It also comes in quite handy when needing NPCs statistics to flesh out more detailed adventures you may be working on, saving you the trouble of rolling them all up yourself.

* Bandits/Guerillas
* Barbarian Warriors
* Functionaries
* Guards (mid and high tech)
* Street Thugs
* Belters
* Corsairs
* Merchants
* Navy Personnel
* Scouts
* Army Personnel (low, mid, and high tech)
* Vehicle Crew
* Sydite Brute Squads
* Vargr Mercenaries
* Aslan Shock Troops
* Imperial Marines

As an added bonus are 19 basic adventure seeds involving each type of NPC in the book!

76 Gunmen, when you just don't have time to build those Thugs to show your players that the Universe is truly not a friendly place!

76641.name: Fighting Ships
76641.description:
From the web site:

The Imperial Navy is the dominant military force in Charted Space. This volume reveals what the navy does, how it does it, and what tools it uses.

TA 7: Fighting Ships starts off with a comprehensive look at the Imperial Navy, starting with its long and prestigious history and moving on to the technology and design concepts involved in creating a fighting starship. Naval missions are given a thorough treatment, as are the roles of the various different ship classes and their organization into squadrons, task groups and fleets.

Also detailed are many of the warship classes in service in 993, including:

* The awesome Perisher class fast dreadnought
* The humble Dryad fighter
* The brand-new and experimental Azhanti High Lightning class fleet intruder
* The venerable Saberwolf class destroyer
* The highly-praised Atlantic class heavy cruiser
* The much-cursed Fer-de-Lance destroyer
* The lethal Grigot class strike fighter
* The death-or-glory Seydlitz class strike monitor

Each class is discussed in terms of its history and possible future, its role and its unique characteristics.

Fighting Ships covers all sizes of ships, and can provide encounters ranging from a battle fleet to a patrol ship, a system defense monitor to a fighter.

These are the vessels that fought the Solomani Rim War and the Third Frontier War. Traveller players using other eras may encounter earlier or later versions of these ships, making TA7 an indispensable resource for the Traveller Referee.

76642.name: Counter-Strike: Condition Zero

videogamehonor.29261: 2004 Golden Joystick Best Online Game of the Year Nominee

76642.description:
Counter-Strike: Condition Zero (CS:CZ or CZ) is a multiplayer video game and the follow-up to Counter-Strike. The game was released in 2004 using the GoldSrc Half-Life engine. CS:CZ features a multiplayer mode, which features updated character models, textures, maps and other graphical tweaks. Unlike other Counter-Strike games, Condition Zero also contains a single-player mission pack with the player unlocking maps and more efficient bots as they pass certain requirements for each map while playing as a counter terrorist. These requirements include targets such as "kill 3 enemies with a glock" or "win a round in 45 seconds".

Condition Zero also introduces the Counter-Strike bot.

Source: Wikipedia, "Counter Strike: Condition Zero," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

76643.name: Mouse Trap
76643.description:
[User summary]

A maze game similar to Pac-Man, but with cats, mice, and cheese.

videogame.90543: Arcade's Greatest Hits: The Midway Collection 2

76644.name: BurgerTime

videogamecompilation.90543: Arcade's Greatest Hits: The Midway Collection 2

76644.description:
BurgerTime (バーガータイム) is a 1982 arcade game created by Data East for its DECO Cassette System. The game's original title, Hamburger, was changed to BurgerTime before its introduction to the US. The player is chef Peter Pepper, who must walk over hamburger ingredients located across a maze of platforms while avoiding pursuing characters. The game was popular in arcades. In the US, Data East USA licensed BurgerTime for distribution by Bally Midway. The Data East and Midway versions are distinguished by the manufacturer's name on the title screen and by the marquee and cabinet artworks.

Source: Wikipedia, "BurgerTime," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

76645.name: Solar Winds: The Escape
76645.description:
In Solar Winds, you are Jake Stone, a bounty hunter who, through several missions, uncovers a secret coalition between the government of your home solar system and a race of unidentified aliens. Upon further investigation, you find out that, in fact, there is more than one solar system involved… And what is really happening is that three easily-provoked races are being held by a more technologically advanced race in a small cluster of solar systems, and kept there by a force field around them. Hyperdrive technology has been sabotaged, and the 'keys', jump points between solar systems, kept secret.

This game was originally shareware. Registration did not unlock any features of this game, but by registering you were given a copy of the sequel.

Source: Wikipedia, "Solar Winds," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

76646.name: Solar Winds: Galaxy
76646.description:
In ... Solar Winds II, you are Jake Stone, ... and now you are in a zoo. Seven systems have been set up by members of the same race that rescued you and each system contains a species. They are monitored and pushed and prodded, and through a series of jobs that take you from one system to another you are contacted by the same resistors that rescued you previously. They help smuggle you outside of the barriers where you destroy the controller and free all the captive races.

This game was included when registering Solar Winds.

Source: Wikipedia, "Solar Winds," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

76647.name: One Must Fall: 2097
76647.description:
Released in 1994 by Epic MegaGames, One Must Fall: 2097 replaces the human combatants typical of contemporary fighter video games with large Human Assisted Robots (HAR). These HARs are piloted through a physical and mental link to the human pilots; however, this is merely a plot concept, and it is never shown on-screen, nor does it factor in to gameplay. Eleven HARs and ten customizable pilots are available for play, along with five arenas and four tournaments. The pilots vary in strength, speed and endurance, thus the many HAR/pilot combinations allow for large replay value.

Unlike in most fighting games of its time, the arenas (except one, the Stadium) contain hazards. For instance, one arena features spikes coming out of the wall that can damage your robot, and one has a floating sphere that, when struck, triggers a fireball from the floor under your opponent.

The game has two main play modes: One-Player Mode, in which the company that markets the robots, World Aeronautics and Robotics (WAR), is holding a competition among its employees to decide who will be selected to oversee the establishment of the first Earth base on Jupiter's moon, Ganymede. The second mode is Tournament Mode, set three years after the first tournament, where HAR battles have become the premier source of entertainment for Earth and you, a new competitor, must win prize money to improve your machine and ultimately become the World Champion.

The game was later patched to include multiplayer support. On February 10, 1999, the game was declared freeware by the developers.

Source: Wikipedia, "One Must Fall: 2097," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

76648.name: Starquake
76648.description:
Starquake is an arcade adventure, platform and maze game written by Dave Collins and Stephen Crow and published by Bubble Bus software in 1985.

...

The player controls BLOB (Bio-Logically Operated Being), whose starship has crashed on a planet. The crash destabilised the core of this planet, and you have to find its parts which are scattered all through the planet and fix it before it explodes. The natural inhabitants of the planet don't like your presence and keep trying to kill you.

Source: Wikipedia, "Starquake (video game)," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

76650.name: Pinball Construction Set
76650.description:
From Wikipedia

Pinball Construction Set created a new genre of computer games—the "builder" or "construction set" class of games. With PCS, users can construct their own virtual pinball arcade machine, by dropping controls onto a table. Controls included bumpers, flippers, spinners and other standard pinball paraphernalia. Attributes such as gravity and the physics model could also be modified. Users could save their creations and develop custom artwork to go along with them. Tables could be saved on floppy disks and freely traded.

videogame.91224: Strong Bad's Cool Game for Attractive People

76651.name: Strong Bad's Cool Game for Attractive People - Episode 1: Homestar Ruiner

videogameseries.6678: Strong Bad's Cool Game for Attractive People

videogamecompilation.91224: Strong Bad's Cool Game for Attractive People

76651.description:
Strong Bad receives an email suggesting he "beat the snot out of" his long-time rival Homestar Runner. When he gets there, however, he discovers Homestar has entered the Free Country USA Tri-annual Race to the End of the Race, and decides it would be even more fun to beat Homestar at his own game than to simply beat him up.

Source: Wikipedia, "Strong Bad's Cool Game for Attractive People," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

videogame.91224: Strong Bad's Cool Game for Attractive People

76652.name: Strong Bad's Cool Game for Attractive People - Episode 2: Strong Badia the Free

videogameseries.6678: Strong Bad's Cool Game for Attractive People

videogamecompilation.91224: Strong Bad's Cool Game for Attractive People

76652.description:
As the episode begins, The King of Town institutes an e-mail tax. Strong Bad is the most heavily affected. However, being unaware of the existence of the tax, he is put under house arrest (with an explosive collar around his neck), a predicament that leads him to unite the citizens to rise up against the authorities. Strong Bad then declares his own plot of land (an empty lot featuring a fence, a spare tire, and a graffiti'd stop sign, which Strong Bad has named "Strong Badia") an independant nation.

Source: Wikipedia, "Strong Bad's Cool Game for Attractive People," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

videogame.91224: Strong Bad's Cool Game for Attractive People

76653.name: Strong Bad's Cool Game for Attractive People - Episode 3: Baddest of the Bands

videogameseries.6678: Strong Bad's Cool Game for Attractive People

videogamecompilation.91224: Strong Bad's Cool Game for Attractive People

76653.description:
As the game opens, Strong Bad's FunMachine (an Atari 2600-like video game system) suddenly breaks. Strong Bad does not have the money to get it fixed, however. In an attempt to get money, he organizes and a Battle Royale of the Bands, complete with local bands and celebrity guest stars—the 80's hair band Limozeen. When this still does not cover the fee, Strong Bad is forced to organize his own rock band and claim the cash prize.

Source: Wikipedia, "Strong Bad's Cool Game for Attractive People," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

videogame.91224: Strong Bad's Cool Game for Attractive People

76654.name: Strong Bad's Cool Game for Attractive People - Episode 4: Dangeresque 3: The Criminal Projective

videogameseries.6678: Strong Bad's Cool Game for Attractive People

videogamecompilation.91224: Strong Bad's Cool Game for Attractive People

76654.description:
This episode gets its scenario from an in-joke in the website. The episode is actually the "film" Dangeresque 3. He invites his friends over to his basement for the film's premiere. The player then assumes the role of Dangeresque, embracing the cliches and tropes of the action film genre, with the movie looking like a very low budget film.

Source: Wikipedia, "Strong Bad's Cool Game for Attractive People," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

videogame.91224: Strong Bad's Cool Game for Attractive People

76655.name: Strong Bad's Cool Game for Attractive People - Episode 5: 8-Bit Is Enough

videogameseries.6678: Strong Bad's Cool Game for Attractive People

videogamecompilation.91224: Strong Bad's Cool Game for Attractive People

76655.description:
The story begins at the end of the Dangeresque 3: The Criminal Projective when Strong Bad jumps off of the couch and hits the Trogdor arcade machine. The Trogdor arcade machine grows an arm and legs and comes to life. Strong Sad claims that Strong Bad damaged the 8-bit containment field and needs to order a replacement. Sadly, through an odd series of events, the containment field is broken, resulting in the world of videogames and the world of Free Country USA combining. Video game elements and characters begin invading the real world, and vice versa. In the ensuing chaos, Trogdor escapes his game and "burninates" Strong Badia. Strong Bad must defeat his fiery creation once and for all, by getting party members from other games to advance to the dungeon of the beast and restore balance between the two worlds.

Source: Wikipedia, "Strong Bad's Cool Game for Attractive People," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

76656.name: Drakens land
76656.description:
From the back of the bock (user translated):

Eastern China was a country overflowing with fish and rice, and it fed millions of people. The last 50 years have made this an inaccessible wilderness of swamps, jungles and deserts created by the foolishness of humanity.

This book contains an adventure for Mutant 2089, set in the most dangerous wilderness of Neoasia - the rainbow forest.

The deeper into the forest one gets, the more horrible the threats.

76657.name: Cyberzonen
76657.description:
From the back of the bock (user translated):

When you have been there, you always go back. It becomes a poison. The darkness. The light the weaves around the system crystals. Systems that curve towards you when you get too close. Black ice, grey ice, red ice.

Welcome to the Cyberzone.

This book contains the rules for travelling in Cyberkosmos, as well as to high-tech adventures for Mutant.

76658.name: Mutant SVOT
76658.description:
From the back of the bock (user translated):

In Mutant SVOT describes high level criminals and law enforcment in the mutant-city. A detalied account of the 2090s crime and punishment, as well as new career and equipment - all you need to be a complete SVOT.

76659.name: Look-a-Likes
76659.description:
A challenging children's lotto game with a difference

Each of the boards in this game shows one motif nine times. Each differs only in minor detail. At first glance, all motifs are so similar that a child is obliged to really scrutinize the details in order to match up pictures and cards. There are six boards, of differing difficulty.

Although billed as lotto, this game is more of a solo puzzle than a game, with the child attempting to match up their 9 cards, and then checking them with the transparent checking sheet. One point is given for each correct card. If playing with several players everyone stops when one player has finished, which brings in a competitive speed element to the game.

76660.name: Ypsilon 5 - Sönderfallets mörker
76660.description:
From introduction(user translated):

The city in 2089 is a self-sustained world with sparks of life and light that hides in the darkness of crime. Steel and glass constructions glow in the light of the neon signs, and the streets and bridges are set on fire by the sweeps of the searchlights.

In this chaotic world the mega cartels are about to drown in their own automated swamp. What would happen if an even bigger disaster then the current one, would break ut.

From the back of the bock (user translated):

This is an adventure module for Mutant 2089 that includes the action-packed adventure "Sönderfallets Mörker. It also includes a description of one of the districts in the mega-city Ypsilon 5.

76661.name: Berlin City 2092
76661.description:
User Summary:

A box set about Berlin in the year 2092.

The description of the city is divided into three books. The first one includes and overview of the cities 139 sectors, its corporations, laws and infrastructure. In the second book you will find detailed descriptions of three of the sectors. The third book is for the player, it comes in the form of a tourist guide for businesspeople visiting Berlin.

The book also includes a large color map of Berlin and a booklet of other maps.

76662.name: Drakar och Demoner (2nd Edition)
76662.description:
Back of the Box
Drakar och Demoner - det annorlunda spelet.

Den flock med orcher som har jagat dig, befinner sig nu nedanför den kulle där du och ditt bevingade riddjur inväntar deras attack. Orcherna avanserar sakta framåt, skrikande och tjutande, medan de svingar sina kroksablar i luften. Du drar ditt svärd och gör dig beredd. Platsen är vald med omtanke, eftersom bara ett par fiender i taget kan anfalla dig. De första orcherna är nu inom räckhåll, och deras sabelhugg viner genom luften, men tack vare din skicklighet avvärjer du attacken. Orcherna backar snabbt och samlas nedanför kullen medan de livligt diskuterar situationen. Du höjer ditt svärd mot den gröna himlen i en segergest...

Det här skulle kunna hända just dig! I Drakar och Demoners rollspelsvärld är allting möjligt och det är din fantasi och improvisationsförmåga som avgör hur roligt spelet är.

Du blir en äventyrare på uppdrag och tillsammans med dina medspelare upplever du ett farligt äventyr. Ni bestämmer själva vad som ska hända och hur spelet ska utvecklas.

User Translation
Dragons and Demons - the game different from others.

The horde of orchs that have hunted you are now at the foot of the hill wher you and your winged steed await their charge. The orchs advance slowly, screaming and howling, while swinging their crooked sabers through the air. You draw your sword and make ready. The place is chosen deliberately, only a few enemies a ta time can attack you. The first couple of orchs are now in range and their saber slashes cuts through the air, but thanks to your skills you parry the attack succesfully. The orchs back down quickly and gather at the foot of the hill while discussing the situation lively. You raise your sword towards the sky in a gesture of victory...

This could happen to you! In the roleplaying world of Dragons and Demons anything can happen and your fantasy and ability of improvisation decides how fun the game is.

You become an adventurer on a mission and together with your co-players you experience a dangerous adventure. You decide together what will happen and how the game should evolve.

Contents
- Rules booklet
- Adventure booklet (containing the adventures Spindelkonungens pyramid and Skelettbyns hemlighet)
- Character sheets
- Square grid map tile
- Game example booklet
- Cardboard figures

76663.name: Tower of the Stargazer
76663.description:
From the back of the book

Legends tell of a wizard so arrogant that he felt the entire sky was naught but a lens for him to view the stars. So great was the hubris and defiance of this man that the gods smote him with the power of storm and fire. Oh did the wizard laugh at such a pathetic gesture. He did not fear the gods, for he drew his knowledge from something greater. Something darker.

The legend of this wizard grew, first whispered by men in fear, and later in awe. The wizard, they said, attacked the gods just as they had attacked him. And his joy only grew as the land around him died.

But then there was no more news. No more talk. Something had finally brought the wizard low, for though the sky still blazed down on him and his abode, he no longer blazed back.

And now you're going to walk right through this wizard's front door.

Tower of the Stargazer is a specially designed introductory module with material specifically for beginning Referees, with notes detailing not only what is included in the adventure, but why.

For Beginning Players, Characters, and Referees.


User summary

The first print run was 800 copies.

76664.name: Hammers of the God

rpgpodcastepisode.4110: RPG Circus Season 2 Episode 12 - Hell hath no Fury like Hellfrost

76664.description:
From the back of the book

By the Sign of the Hammer!

A mysterious man and a promise of treasure to be won are all that are required to set any adventurer worth the name into the wilderness. But sometimes what is found is far more than treasure.

Many that are good and noble will kill to make sure the secrets to be found under the old mountain stay buried. May that enter the darkness will become beguiled by the splendor of the halls in which they walk, mesmerized by the riches to be found there, never realizing that death follows their every move.

Dwarves never forget a grudge. But what if they hold that grudge against themselves?

Beware the god who has been discarded.

An adventure for character levels 3-5.


User summary

The first print run had a size of 500 copies.

76665.name: Weird New World
76665.description:
From the back of the book

JOURNEY TO THE TOP OF THE WORLD

The coldest north is the ultimate frontier for adventure, and nature can prove just as challenging a foe as any monster.

Included in Weird New World:


A large full color map detailing a continent-sized arctic area
Over forty encounter areas, many of which are suitable for expansion into full adventure scenarios in their own right
Rules covering survival in the furthest north
The ultimate secret of a fallen race
An open-ended sandbox setting that you can insert seamlessly into your campaign!



User summary

The first print run had a size of 800 copies. This book is also included in the Lamentations of the Flame Princess box set.

76666.name: Firestorm: Warsaw
76666.description:
Firestorm:Warsaw takes place in 1944 during the Warsaw Uprising in which the people of Warsaw/Poland sought to liberate themselves after 5 years of German occupation. Players will take control of either the German or the Polish forces. Not only will players be able to roll dice to simulate combat achieving results such as destroyed, retreat etc. they will also be able to move their forces from one area of the game board to another. Other than that there is very little wargame 'chrome'; And at best this game provides an introduction to Battlefront's Firestorm series.

Firestorm: Warsaw is a game of conflict simulation for 2 people in which victory will be determined by the player who occupies areas with a higher total point sum than their opponent at the end fo six turns.

Firestorm: Warsaw includes:

1 Set of rules
1 Gameboard




The game is part of a series of Firestorm games, although this one is much smaller than the other two.

It may be noted that the rules for the game are included within a 30-page PDF, which also contains materials relating to gaming the Warsaw Uprising using the Flames of War rule system. The Firestorm:Warsaw game is not an expansion to Flames of War, but rather a stand-alone game which can be played using the material provided, plus a few counters and figures and dice which will need to be provided by the players.

76667.name: Staadt
76667.description:
Anno Domini 1213. This is a time of the greatest economical boom since the fall of the Roman Empire. Townsfolk, merchants and craftsmen from the whole Europe migrate to Silesia, their promised land. In the next 100 years near 100 cities will be founded and almost every city is located on the Magdeburg Law. That means each city is built in the same way. Market square is a heart of the city with the most important municipal buildings around it. Along the streets, running from the market to the city gates, merchants and craftsmen have their houses, shops and workshops. To stay above water in hard medieval economy they gather together in guilds. Cities always need security, which is granted by the band of strong walls with defense towers. Behind them citizens and newcomers can feel safe protected by the city guard.
In Staadt, 2 to 4 players take the role of medieval city builders in Silesia. Prince Kazimierz and bishop Wawrzyniec gives you a mission of great importance – to build the gratest and the wealthiest city in Silesia in just 4 years. The one who will develop his district better and quicker than his opponents will receive the golden chain of Major of the City and the eternal favour of the Prince.
Amen.

Game features:


3D game experience
Realistic economy model
Wooden box/board
Great replayability


English book of rules under construction!

76668.description:
Move your mover – either Greg, Rowley, Fregley or Manny – around the game board. Depending on where you end up, you’ll be playing different categories. In Who Said What all players will secretly write down an answer to a question like if you could only eat one food for the rest of your life, what would it be? Go through the answers and try to guess who said what. Correct answers move you closer to finish. But wrong answers can give you the cheese. Try to get rid of it as fast as you can.

For 3 or 4 players, ages 7 and up.

Contents: Game board,4 movers, game cards, card box, cheese piece, game die, rules

-From the Publisher's website
76668.name: Diary of a Wimpy Kid: Cheese Touch

rpg.6687: How We Came to Live Here

76669.name: How We Came to Live Here
76669.description:
From the back cover:
"HOW WE CAME TO LIVE HERE is a story-telling game which evokes the myths and legends of the Native American people. Within the game, characters must navigate their own ambitions and desires, the conflicting demands of their fellow villagers, and the ever-present threat of monsters and natural disasters from outside: your own ambition could lead you down a path of corruption."

boardgameimplementation.32849: Cat in The Hat:  I Can do that!

76670.description:
Kids game where 3 cards are selected from a laid out grid of cards (similar to Memory) to try to find one each of the three different types of cards in order create a wacky activity.
An Action Card (such as Crab Walk, Hop, Dance)
A Location Card (such as to the window, or into the kitchen)
A card as to where to hold a foam fishbowl (such as under your chin, or between your elbows).
If one of each type of card is not drawn all three are put back (similar to Memory), and it is the next player's turn.

If one of each card is selected, the player gets to act out the activity described by the 3 cards, and gets to keep the cards.
Player with the most cards when all are drawn is the winner.

Includes a foam fishbowl, and 24 cards
76670.name: The Cat in the Hat I Can Do That! Card Game

76671.name: All for One: Régime Diabolique (Ubiquity)

rpghonor.21795: 2011 UK Games Expo Best Role-playing Game Winner

76671.description:
Publisher's description:

The year is 1636 and France is a troubled nation.

A great and terrible evil gnaws at its core.

Darkness stalks the land.

All that stands between chaos and order are the King's Musketeers.

Explore a France of swashbuckling action, powerful magic, daring deeds, courtly intrigue, witty repartee, and vile monsters! The characters are France's bravest and proudest defenders, the King's Musketeers. Pitted against them is a plethora of corrupt nobles, black magicians, fell demons, and twisted secret societies.

Set at the height of power of Cardinal Richelieu and Louis XIII, All for One: Régime Diabolique mixes the action of literary works such as the Count of Monte Cristo and The Three Musketeers with horror and intrigue to create a unique, vibrant setting. The high-action is powered by Ubiquity, an innovative role playing game system that emphasizes storytelling and cinematic action.

Strap on your sword, salute the King, and prepare to fight the creatures of darkness!

76672.name: Zipp-Zapp-Zahlendrachen
76672.description:
The game consists of two sets of 13 cards each. Ten cards in each set show numbers between 1 and 100, the other three show dragons. Each of the two players gets one set.
Each player now plays one card, face down. The cards are revealed simultaneously. The player of the higher card gets the difference between the two cards in points. A dragon voids a "trick", nobody gets any points.
The first player to reach 100 points is the winner. When all cards are played, each player takes up his/her cards again for another round.

boardgamehonor.22651: 2013 UK Games Expo Best Abstract Game Winner

76674.description:
String Railway is a unique train game that consists of colored strings, tokens, station tiles, and a board for scoring. To set up, first place the string tied in a big circle on the table to establish the field area for the game. Next, place a small circle of string to represent mountains and a line of string to represent a river. Finally, place the main stations for each player equal distances apart from one another.

On a turn, you draw and place a station tile, then try to place a railroad string between your stations in an effort to connect them in order to form your own train network. Connected stations earn victory points (VPs).

After five turns, the game ends and the player with the most VPs wins.
76674.name: String Railway

76675.name: A4 gewinnt
76675.description:
The game is played on a A1 size board which is divided into 64 A7 fields. The two players hold A7 sized cards in their own color. At first, the players take turns putting one of their cards into each of the four quadrants of the board, afterwards they can put them onto any field. When all cards have been placed, the cards can be moved to adjacent fields. Two adjacent cards can be moved together. When a player manages to form a four card (A5 sized) rectangle, he/she can take one of the opponent's cards out and place it on the rectangle - these cards are now secure (and can be moved together, too).

When a player manages to form a second A5 rectangle, he/she is the winner. The game promotes the standard paper sizes.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

76676.name: Busstop
76676.description:
First Edition
Almost cards represent passengers. There are 5 kinds of Passengers like kids, highschool girls, salary men, seniors and ET(the Extra-Terrestrials).
Each card has a rank from 1 to 81 (expressed years old).

Each player has 3 kinds of buses. Each bus has limit of passengers: 3, 4 or 5. Same kind of passengers must ride same bus. But ET can change the rule.

Each round, several passengers will appear at the field.
Then, each player select a card from hand simultaneously.
According to the rank you played, you can get passenger(s) from the field and/or played.

After that, you must line passengers got to your Busstop or make ride some of your buses.

When filled, the bus will go and you get VP from passenger rode.

The game will finish when all cards are played.

Second Edition
They changed cards into tiles.
Numbers on the tiles also changed.

76677.name: Digger
76677.description:
"Digger is a Canadian computer game released by Windmill Software in 1983, popular in the era of the IBM PC with a CGA graphics card and monitor. It generally requires a genuine CGA card and runs too fast on computers faster than the original IBM PC 4.77 MHz. In an exception to the CGA requirement, it is possible to use a CGA emulator to run Digger on a Hercules graphics card."

Gameplay

Many features of Digger are similar to those in the arcade games Mr. Do! and Dig Dug. As in those games, the player is placed in an underground maze, and can dig horizontal and vertical tunnels through it. At least one tunnel already exists at the start of play. At various points on the board are emeralds (usually in clusters) and bags of gold. Monsters (initially in the 'nobbin' form) appear at the top right-hand corner. If earth is excavated from under a gold bag, then the bag will wobble for a few seconds and then drop; if it falls more than one row, it will break open after falling, releasing gold which can be collected. Bags can also be pushed left or right into vertical paths, with similar results. Falling bags will squash monsters that they fall on, but they will also squash the digger. The digger also has a weapon, which will fire in a straight line, but takes several seconds to recharge (taking longer as the levels go higher).

Monsters will sometimes change from the 'nobbin' form to the 'hobbin' form, more frequently on higher levels. Hobbins also have the power to excavate, and can destroy emeralds and gold bags while so doing.

When a monster is killed, another will appear at the top right-hand corner of the screen, up to a maximum number which depends on the level. Once all the monsters for the level have been created, a cherry appears in their place. If the digger collects this, bonus mode is entered, and for about fifteen seconds (which decreases as the game level gets higher) the digger is able to eat the monsters. Accordingly, the monsters now run away from the digger rather than towards it (similar to Pac-Man).

A level ends when all the emeralds are gone or all the monsters have been killed.

Source: Wikipedia, "Digger (computer game)," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

76678.name: Fishing Derby
76678.description:
"In Fishing Derby, two fishermen sit on opposite docks over a lake filled with fish (and a shark that passes through). Using the joystick the player is able to move his line left right and up and down in the water. When a fish is hooked, the line slowly comes up to the surface of the water. Pressing the fire button on the joystick reels in the fish faster. However, if both fishermen have fish hooked, only one person can reel theirs in (the one who hooked theirs first). The shark that roams the water will try to eat hooked fish before they surface.

The objective for both fishermen is to reach 99 pounds of fish first. There are six rows of fish; the top two rows have 2 lb. fish, the middle two rows have 4 lb. fish, and the two bottom rows have 6 lb. fish. The more valuable fish sit at the bottom, but they are harder to bring in as they run a higher risk of being eaten by the shark.

The game's two variants are simply single player and multi-player. In both games the objective is to reach 99 lb. of fish first."

Source: Wikipedia, "Fishing Derby," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

76679.name: Skiing
76679.description:
"Skiing is a single player only game, in which the player uses the joystick to control the direction and speed of a stationary skier at the top of the screen, while the background graphics scroll upwards, thus giving the illusion the skier is moving. The player must avoid obstacles, such as trees and moguls. The game cartridge was programmed with five variations each of two principal games. In the downhill mode, the player's goal is to reach the bottom of the ski course as rapidly as possible, while a timer records his relative success. In the slalom mode, the player must similarly reach the end of the course as rapidly as he can, but must at the same time pass through a series of gates (indicated by a pair of closely-spaced flagpoles). Each gate missed counts as a penalty against the player's time."

Source: Wikipedia, Skiing (Atari 2600), available under the CC-BY-SA License.

76680.name: Freeway
76680.description:
"One or two players control chickens who can be made to run across a ten lane highway filled with traffic in an effort to "get to the other side." Every time a chicken gets across a point is earned for that player. If hit by a car, a chicken is forced back either slightly, or in some modes, pushed back to the bottom of the screen. The winner of a two player game is the player who has scored the most points in the two minutes, sixteen seconds allotted.

The chickens are only allowed to move up or down. The chicken sprite has limited animation and a cluck sound is heard when a chicken is struck by a car.

Comparisons are often made to Frogger, which has different gameplay but also features crossing a street filled with moving vehicles. Both games were developed independently at the same time. Similarities did help sales when Frogger was popular in the arcades and a home version was not yet available."

Source: Wikipedia, "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freeway_%28video_game%29,"; available under the [ http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/ CC-BY-SA License].

76681.description:
In The Kingdoms of Crusaders, players assemble units to create armies and overwhelm opponents competing for the same territories. The game includes components for a two-player game; by combining two sets, up to four players can compete.

Units are represented by cards, with each card depicting the forces in it with color-coded symbols across its top. The forces come in five strengths, which from weakest to strongest are Lance, Bow, Sword, Helmet and Banner. For example, a unit (card) with Sword and Helmet will have across the top: blank, blank, green, yellow, blank. Each player starts with a hand of five cards and a location card on the table depicting five territories, which is where a player lays his cards.

On a turn, a player draws a card from the deck, then lays one card from his hand into one of the territories next to his location card. Each territory can have no more than four cards in it. Once you've played four cards into a territory, you've determined the final strength of the army there. If the same symbol is on all four cards, you've created a Regiment; the same symbol on only three cards creates a Battalion, and the same symbol on only two cards creates a Company. (You can create multiple Regiments, Battalions and Companies in the same territory.)

To determine who wins the battle in a territory, compare each player's army in this territory. The player whose army has the most Regiments wins; if players are tied for the number of Regiments, then the player with the strongest Regiments wins; if players have equally strong Regiments, then the player with the most Battalions wins; and so on. Even if his opponent(s) have not completed their armies, a player can win a territory by proving that it's impossible for someone to create a stronger army in the same territory.

When a player wins a territory, he places a lowest available victory marker on this army. Once all five victory markers have been claimed, the game ends. The player who collects the most markers wins; if players are tied for the number of victory markers, then the player whose markers have the lowest sum wins.
76681.name: The Kingdoms of Crusaders

76683.name: Stampede
76683.description:
"The objective of Stampede is to round up all of the cattle you encounter. To do so, the player must lasso each one in order to capture it. The player is initially only allowed to let two cattle pass; if a third one slips by, the game is over.

An important caveat to this is that the player gets one extra free pass for every 1,000 points scored. So, if a player were at 2,000 points and had not yet let any cattle pass, then he or she would be allowed to let four cattle pass before the fifth one ended the game (assuming she did not reach 3,000)."

Source: Wikipedia, "Stampede (video game)," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

76684.name: Launch Pad
76684.description:
The space race is on!

You are battling to build the biggest, baddest rockets possible and send them soaring into space. Each rocket requires metal, fuel, and the expertise needed for liftoff. As you build your rockets, beware of your opponents, who are eager to steal your goods and sabotage your work--you may even have some tricks of your own to thwart their progress.

All the while, the launch pad is being constructed--as soon as it’s ready, the rockets that are "go" for launch will blast off into space, leaving all others behind!

Do you have what it takes to make your rockets soar before it’s too late?

76685.name: Barnstorming
76685.description:
"The player must pilot a biplane through a series of barns in the shortest time possible while dodging windmills, weather vanes, and geese. Bumping into anything slows down the plane for a couple of seconds, increasing the overall time.

There are four levels of play determined by the game select switch. Game 1 is Hedge Hopper (10 barns), game 2 is Crop Duster (15 barns), game 3 is Stunt Pilot (15 barns), and game 4 is Flying Ace (25 barns). In the first three games, the course layout of barns, windmills, and even geese do not change, making it easy to memorize the layout. Game 4 is the only game with a random course."

Source: Wikipedia, "Barnstorming (video game)," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

76686.description:
The game consists of eight tiles with three pictures on each of them. There are also 24 picture cards showing the same pictures. A path is laid out with the tiles; the cards are placed face down around the path.
The active player flips over a card. If the picture matches one of the three on the tile in front of him/her and, he/she can move forward to that picture on the tile and flip over another card, etc. If there is no match, it is the next player's turn. If the picture is already occupied, the active player ends his/her turn as well. When the last player has left a tile, that tile is taken away and placed at the end of the path, so that the path keeps getting longer and the players have to remember several pictures in a row if they ever want to reach it. The first player to reach the last tile is the winner.

The theme of the game is the German TV series "Bernd das Brot".

(User summary by HilkMAN)
76686.name: Ab durch die Mitte

76687.name: Robot Tank
76687.description:
The game has the player remotely control a futuristic robot tank, whose mission is to stop enemy rebel tanks rampaging across the countryside from reaching downtown Santa Clara. The tank is equipped with radar to locate enemy squadrons.

The game was innovative in that, instead of the player's tank being destroyed with a hit from an enemy, it was merely damaged, losing some capabilities such as radar or speed (enough damage would eventually destroy the tank). The game also features 24-hour gameplay (that is, combat could take place at any time of the day or night) and varying weather (rain, snow, fog), which added additional challenge in tracking enemy combatants.

Source: Wikipedia, "Robot Tank," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

76688.name: A Sickness in Silverton
76688.description:
Publisher Blurb:

A Sickness in Silverton is designed for a Druid, level 3-5, powered by Pathfinder Roleplaying Game.

A grave illness has befallen the little folk of Silverton, and only the town drunk and a Dwarven prospector have avoided the debilitating malaise. Do you have the wits and will to uncover the source of this sinister sickness?

76689.name: Beat 'Em & Eat 'Em
76689.description:
Beat 'Em and Eat 'Em is a pornographic video game developed for the Atari 2600 by Mystique. It was released in 1982. Although the game sold poorly upon release, its graphic nature has earned it a cult following and much infamy. It is often referenced as one of the worst video games ever made, a distinction it shares with other Mystique titles, like Custer's Revenge.

In this game, the player controls a pair of nude women who scuttle back and forth underneath a building where a man with a notably large penis is constantly masturbating from the roof top. The player's objective is to maneuver these women so that they consume the man's semen (which is colored yellow in the game) before it hits the ground. When all the semen is caught, the two women turn to the screen and lick their lips. These game-play mechanics closely mimic those of a large group of games (e.g. Kaboom!) in which the object is to catch objects thrown by an ever-faster moving character. A score of 69 points, and every 69 points thereafter (138, 207, 276, etc.) earns an extra life.

Source: Wikipedia, "Beat 'Em & Eat 'Em," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

76690.name: Sinistar
76690.description:
Sinistar is an arcade game released by Williams in 1982. It belongs to a class of video games from the 1980s called "twitch games". Other "twitch games" include Tempest, Defender, and Robotron: 2084. Sinistar was developed by RJ Mical, Sam Dicker, Jack Haeger, and Noah Falstein. Sinistar's voice was supplied by John Doremus.

Source: Wikipedia, "Sinistar," available under the CC-BY-SA License.

76691.name: Eye for an Eye
76691.description:
Eye for an Eye puts a themed-spin on the parlor game "Wink Murder" (aka, Wink Death), a game in which one player is a murderer who kills people by winking at them. This player wants to off as many other players as possible before someone catches his murderous wink and accuses him of the crimes.

In Eye for an Eye, the players belong to a group of priests in Britannia known as the Ovates. From the rules: "It is the dream of every Ovate to become a Druid, but the test is a terrible one requiring courage,intelligence and stamina." One to three Druids hide among the group of Ovates, and they can hypnotize an Ovate by winking at that players. The Druids don't know one another's identities, but if one Druid winks at another, the wink has no effect. The game ends when either only one Ovate remains unhypnotized (this player being the game's loser for failing to detect any Druids after so much opportunity) or an Ovate accuses someone of being a Druid (in which one or the other player is the game's loser). The loser must then perform the tests chosen by players at the start of the game from the included deck of 34 tests, with the test categories being "Gallantry", "Find Out About Me", "Don't Be Shy" and "Surprise".

The Austrlian Wink Death features a more traditional approach to the party game, with one player being the winker and up to 32 others being the winkees. The murder victims die in the manner depicted on their character card. Any player can accuse another of being the winker, but should the accusation prove incorrect, then both players are out and the game continues. Wink Death includes rules for three other games that use the same deck of cards.

76692.name: Dwarves' Companion
76692.description:
From the back of the book:

Inside this book is the story of how the Dwarven race was first conveived, its early history, its trial and tribulations with both Elvenkind and mankind. The story of the sundering of the Dwarven race, the children of Durin, Ptah and Lothgaringer and the secret of what happend to the children of Ptah when they sealed themselves undergroun.

There are revised rules for generating Dwarven characters along with new vocations, new Dwarven magic, Dwarven religion and details on the many clans that make up Dwarven society.

Bring the Dwarves alive in your Chivalry & Sorcery campaign and itroduce the magic of the Runes to your players.

76693.name: Flip 'N Score
76693.description:
Simple Hockey card game. Each player uses one team deck of 54 cards. Decks are available for all 30 NHL teams and licensed by the NHL, NHLPA and NHLOA.

Players have a hand of 5 cards in which they use to try and gain control of the puck and then play a shot on goal. The defensive attempts to play cards to either steal the puck, block a shot or force a face-off.

First Edition has decks for the Original Six teams.
Second Edition has decks for all Canadian teams.
Third Edition has decks for every NHL team.

76695.name: Roll Your Own
76695.description:
ROLL YOUR OWN

A constructible dice game using NESTORtiles.
Players construct custom dice then roll them in head-to-head combat.

NUMBER OF PLAYERS: 2-???
EQUIPMENT: One or more sets of standard NESTORtiles.

RULES:


Each player builds a custom D6 die using tiles from a common pool. The pips on all 6 of each die's sides must initially total no more than 21. (This will change throughout gameplay.)
Players then ROLL their dice, with high roll winning. Ties are ignored in a two-player game; if more than 2 are playing, ties for high number are re-rolled until there is a winner.
A ROUND continues until one player has won six* ROLLs.
